[7:06] Will the BFR be capable of a round-trip moon flight without refueling?
Yes*

I believe Elon Musk addressed this in one of the conference videos (though which one escapes me now).
The * part being that for the in earth orbit refuelling part, the BFR's orbit will be elliptical, not circular.
I.e. It refuels some, does part of the orbit change to get to the moon, then finally tops up fully.

I do not believe they went into detail about how elliptical the orbit will be, but I suspect that will also depend on where on the moon you aim to land and return from, as that also impacts fuel costs.

So what happens to the engine after the satellite is detached and put into orbit?

I was wondering about de-orbit burning on GTO as they were deploying the satellite. At separation, the upper stage is heading upwards to apogee at geosynchronous orbit height, where it will have low velocity. The satellite uses an orbital insertion burn to speed up to geosynchronous velocity (2*pi*(23000+4000)/24) mph (roughly 7000mph). The upper stage isn't going fast enough to stay at that altitude so will plunge back down to perigee. Deorbit burn is best at highest velocity (= lowest orbital height, i.e. perigee).

46:00 Here’s a 2¢ thought: for the live stream, yes, we can definitely deal with a 5s blackout, but don’t you think it would be cool for the ship camera to record the landing and allow the replay of it once it’s stabilized. In that case, this is not for mission control or to even check the status of the landing, but for marketing/visual purpose to see the landing. Even if the replay would be a 10 or even 20s delay, it wouldn’t matter for the audience, but the visual impact would be enormous. It’s all about communication/marketing (and that’s also why SpaceX does this kind of livestream, not only it’s fun for us geeks, but it’s probably good for future clients, or even to give the desire to some kids out there to study to become a future engineer or astronaut). As said, it’s just my 2¢
